definition: (history) a hunting party
autumn/fall/harvest time
surname Qiu
old variant of 秋[qiu1]

to hunt in autumn (archaic)
to pay homage at a mausoleum
Nanhaizi, name used to refer to various places, including 草海[Cao3 hai3], 南苑[Nan2 yuan4] and the Nanhaizi Wetland in Baotou, Inner Mongolia
to go out hunting
to go on a hunting expedition
to hunt
Khalkha, largest subgroup of Mongol people
Chahar Province (former province in North China existing from 1912-1936)
to go on an inspection tour

posthumous title of Hung Taiji 皇太極|皇太极 (1592-1643), eighth son of Nurhaci 努爾哈赤|努尔哈赤, reigned 1626-1636 as Second Khan of Later Jin dynasty 後金|后金, then founded the Qing dynasty 大清 and reigned 1636-1643 as Emperor
Eight Banners, military organization of Manchu later Jin dynasty 後金|后金[Hou4 Jin1] from c. 1600, subsequently of the Qing dynasty
Rehe, Qing dynasty province abolished in 1955 and divided among Hebei, Liaoning and Inner Mongolia/refers to the Qing imperial resort at Chengde/see also 避暑山莊|避暑山庄[bi4 shu3 shan1 zhuang1] (history)
Uliastai, the Qing name for outer Mongolia
to take to the field oneself (of emperor)/to take part in person in an expedition
to have an audience (with the Emperor)
given name of Qing Emperor Xianfeng 咸豐|咸丰

pair of annual sacrificial ceremonies held by the emperor in ancient times: one in the southern suburbs of the capital (bringing offerings to Heaven) and another in the northern suburbs (with offerings to Earth)
